title: black lives matter boston red sox fenway park
story: The team revealed the -foot black and white billboard, which features the words “Black Lives Matter” in Red Sox brand font with the team logo at the end.Located adjacent to Fenway Park, the mural faces the Massachusetts Turnpike and debuted ahead of the teams exhibition game against the Toronto Blue Jays.The billboard was unveiled after the st anniversary of Elijah “Pumpsie” Green debuting as the Red Sox’s first black player in  — making Boston the last MLB team to integrate.In June, the Red Sox displayed “Black Lives Matter” on the scoreboard at the baseball field to show their support.“Our anger and grief must translate to action. We have a responsibility to use our  to amply messages of truth and justice,” the team tweeted at the time.Last month, Red Sox outfielder Jackie Bradley Jr was among several black MLB players to participate in a video supporting the Black Lives Matter movement.Team president and CEO Sam Kennedy wrote in a message to team personnel who have participated in social justice protests: “Please know we stand with you.“Silence in the face of injustice is unacceptable.”Red Sox team management said this week they aren’t anticipating that any of their players will kneel during the national anthem this season, but would support anyone who does.Manager Ron Roenicke said on Tuesday, according to MassLive: “Obviously, it’s a very important topic.”“As far as I know, we don’t have guys who are going to take a knee but certainly we will join in with the other concerns.“It’s a very strong statement that we have, for this organization and how we feel about the fight on equality.”“We haven’t told players you have to do anything,” he said. “We’ve given them the rights, which is what this country is all about, and the freedom to do what they feel strongly about.We have said what we think and what we would like them to do, but we have also given them the opportunity to express themselves.“This organization is okay with it. If they want to take a knee, they can take a knee,” Roenicke said.“I don’t know that anybody’s going to do that, butthey want to, we support them in whatever they want to do.”The Red Sox’s first game of the season against the Baltimore Orioles on Friday at Fenway Park.On Tuesday, members of the Cincinnati Reds took a knee during The Star-Spangled Banner before the team’s exhibition game against the Detroit Tigers in Ohio.Four players — Joey Votto, Amir Garrett, Phillip Ervin, and Alex Blandino — took a knee at Great American Ball Park, as at least six others stood by them.Some of those who were standing placed their hands on the kneeling players’ shoulders and backs, seemingly as a gesture of support.Sports players who kneel as The Star-Spangled Banner plays ahead of games do so as a peaceful protest against racial injustice.The protest began with Colin Kaepernick in , as the then-quarterback for the San Francisco ers sat, then later kneeled, during the anthem at NFL games.He was criticized for years, but the idea of the peaceful protest has changed among many since George Floyd’s death in May.Reds manager David Bell said: The way I see it with our players because I know them so well, whether they were standing or kneeling, it was all out of respect.”On Monday, several San Francisco Giants baseball players — including team manager Gabe Kapler — kneeled during the anthem ahead of the team’s exhibition against Oakland Athletics.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uighur camps fashion industry cotton
story: More than  organisations are urging brands from Adidas to Amazon to end sourcing of cotton and clothing from the Xinjiang region and cut ties with any suppliers in China that benefit from forced labour.This comes amid mounting global pressure on Beijing over its treatment of the Uighur Muslim minority in the region including compulsory sterilisation of women, torture and forced separation of families.United Nations experts estimate that at least a million Uighurs and other Muslims are held in detention centres in Xinjiang – a claim denied by China which says the camps offer vocational training and help fight terrorism.While most brands do not source from factories in Xinjiang, many of their supply chains are likely to be tainted by cotton exported across China, the rights groups said in a letter.More than  per cent of Chinas cotton comes from northwestern Xinjiang, which is home to about  million Uighurs. The human rights coalition said today: “Virtually the entireapparels industry is tainted by forced Uighur and Turkic Muslim labour.”Chloe Cranston, of Anti-Slavery International, said: “There is a high likelihood that every high street and luxury brand runs the risk of being linked to what is happening to the Uighur people.”The Chinese embassies in London and Washington did not respond to requests for comment about the campaigners letter.A spokesperson for the Chinese embassy in the United States earlier this month said the accusation of forced labour in Xinjiang was both  and malicious.The Thomson Reuters Foundation sent emailed questions to more than  leading global retailers about their supply chains in China and the origins of the cotton they sourced.Chinas Uighur Muslims are reportedly being thrown into detention camps for having beards, wearing veils and using the internet.A leaked document detailing the lives of hundreds of Muslims detained in camps in China could be the strongest evidence of Beijing persecuting and punishing religious beliefs, an expert said in February.The personal details of detained Uyghur citizens from southwestern Xinjiang was leaked to CNN and seen by the BBC in  pages of detailed records.The records include how often people pray, how they dress, whom they contact and how their family members behave.It also contains details of investigations into  iniduals, listing their backgrounds, religious habits, and relationships with relatives, neighbours and friends.Chinese authorities say the records are being used to justy the indefinite detention of hundreds of Uighur citizens in heavily fortied internment centers across Xinjiang.The government has claimed it is running a mass deradicalization program targeting potential extremists.Almost all of the brands did not respond directly to the questions, but most said they had anti-forced labour policies and required their suppliers to comply with a code of conduct.All the companies that responded - including Gap, Patagonia and Zara-owner Inditex - said they did not source from factories in Xinjiang, but the majority could not confirm that their supply chain was free of cotton picked from the region.US-based PVH - owner of brands from Calvin Klein to Tommy Hilfiger - said it would cut ties with any factories or mills that produce fabric or use cotton from Xinjiang within a year.Better Cotton Initiative , a global non-profit aiming to improve conditions in the garment sector, said in March it would no longer license so-called Better Cotton from Xinjiang.Companies such as IKEA and HM, who use BCI to source cotton, have previously said they backed the decision to suspend licensing in the region and would no longer source from there.Amid the growing international pressure on China, the US government this month said it blocked an , shipment of hair extensions from a Xinjiang-based business on suspicions that the goods were made with forced labour.A New York Times investigation last week found some Chinese companies making face masks to protect against the coronavirus for both domestic and export markets had used Uighur labour.Our title: british holidaymaker broke back plunging 60ft sleepwalking fell third floor balcony ibiza
story: When college worker Coral Skipp, , was rescued she was also found bleeding from deep wounds, and suffering with broken hips.Screaming with agony, Coral alerted her sleeping fiance, John Lloyd, who awoke at am to find her missing on the last night of their Spanish hols.John said: “She does get night terrors and bad dreams at times, so this is just a horrible, horrible accident.”Coral is lucky to be alive after being treated for a fractured spine, broken hips and multiple stitches from the plunge.The Llansilin, near Welshpool, Powys, resident is being treated at Can Misses Hospital on the Spanish island.John explained: “We got invited out here by a group of friends who had some spare spaces on a flight.We’d all had a fantastic week and went to bed early on the Thursday, and I woke to go to the toilet at around am, and I heard Coral shouting.She fell from a balcony after suffering a bad dream. It was horrible.Former serviceman John added: “It’s not going to be an easy recovery.The smitten couple still have their hearts set on getting married in August next year.A pal has set up a GoFundMe page, which has already received more than £, in donations towards her medical fees after scans and other tests showed her injuries were more serious than first thought.Organiser Netty Pope said: As most know now, our beautul friend Coral has had a serious accident whilst in Ibiza leaving her with broken hips, fractured spine and lots of stitches.We are raising money to aid in her recovery, which is looking like  weeks at least! The money raised will be used to enable her doting partner John to stay and look after her while she is in recovery... his world has been turned upside down.Former serviceman John said he has found Corals near-death experience overwhelming and he appreciates everyones help.John told County Times: Thank you to our friends and family who have been so, so supportive – Coral’s family, my family... my ex-military friends and all of our friends have been fantastic.“The hospital have been absolutely brilliant too and so has the British Consulate.“The money will be there to help family come over to us, but also to help us get home eventually.Support worker Coral’s work colleagues at Derwen College in Gobowen, Powys, sent a get well soon message.Natalie Bellis, Derwen College’s director of human resources, said: “We were sorry to hear from Coral that she’d sustained some serious injuries while on holiday.“We wish her a speedy recovery, and look forward to welcoming her back when she’s fully recovered.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: north korean ghost boats japan blame china
story: Almost  of the ghost vessels have been found in the last five years, and  in the last year alone. One of the most grim discoveries came in December  when officials found the heads of two people and the partially-skeletonised bodies of five as a wooded ship floated to Japans Sado island.A new investigation by NBC News and Global Fishing Watchhas compiled the data and collected startling anecdotes.This includes the story of one Japanese coastguard who says more than  North Koreans have washed up on beaches in the past two years. The reason for the ghost boats is China has sent a previously invisible armada of industrial boats to illegally fish in North Korean waters, researchers claim.This caused desperate North Korean fishermen to risk their lives by going further out to sea in unsafe boats, which became overwhelmed by the harsh waves and swept away.The Kim Jong-un regime is believed to have put more pressure on the fishermen amid food shortages.In fact so many fisherman have now disappeared at sea that some port towns are called widows’ villages.At least  survivors have been rescued and interviewed in the last seven years by Japanese authorities, but they have reportedly refused to answer most questions and demanded to be ed to the secretive country of North Korea. The dark fleets of Chinese ships do not publicly broadcast their location or appear in public monitoring systems, according to the .For a long time, the ghost ships containing corpses or skeletons in fishing grounds in the Sea of Japan was a mystery.It was originally believed that climate change had forced squid from their natural location, forcing North Koreans to go further at sea and become stranded until they died from dehydration or starvation.Many boats that washed up on shore had no-one on board, leaving Japan suspicious that they were carrying spies or even people who travelled there to spread a disease.GFW are a non-profit organisation campaigning for transparency in the fishing industry.They said more than  Chinese vessels fished illegally in the region in , and  in .The group also believe China likely breached UN sanctions that prohibit foreign fishing in North Koreas territorial waters.Jaeyoon Park, a data scientist from Global Fishing Watch, told NBC News: This is the largest known case of illegal fishing perpetrated by a single industrial fleet operating in another nation’s waters.But Chinas Ministry of Foreign Affairs claimed in response that they consistently punished illegal fishing. It did not admit or deny sending its boats into North Korean waters.GOT a story  EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: couple told stop having kids bigger council home norfolk
story: Shirley Purton, , lives with her partner, Luke Lumbard, , and their kids - Isabell, two, Lareece, one, and Matilda, who is  weeks old.The family of five live in a tiny flat in Thetford, Norfolk, which has no outdoor space and limited storage.They called their housing provider, Havebury Housing, to ask about bidding on a bigger home - and were told to stop having kids.Shirley Purton, who cannot work due to health reasons, said: Weve been on a council list since my daughter, Isobel, was first born.My partner spoke to Havebury Housing, they are a housing provider and thats where we bid for properties.They told my partner that it looked like there wouldnt be houses available for a while and to stop having kids.Shirley said that there is a main road right at the back of the building where they live, and that the children cant safely go out to play - but thats not their biggest problem.All five of them are sharing the small flat and the bedroom has to be used for storage.She added: We live in a one bedroom flat, theres five of us who live there. We have a living room, a kitchen, and theres one bedroom with a toilet in the bedroom.Its too small, were happy to make do with the space - I didnt have kids just to get a bigger place. A spokesperson for Havebury Housing said: We are investigating this matter in line with our complaints process.If a member of our team has said something inappropriate, we offer our sincere apologies to the family concerned.We work hard to ensure our customer-facing teams operate professionally and courteously at all times and we will act appropriatelywe find our high standards have not been met.We will liaise directly with the family to resolve any dissatisfaction of service.The Sun Online has contacted Thetford Town Council for comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blackburn luton lockdown coronavirus intervention
story: Both towns have joined Leicester as areas of intervention due to rising numbers of coronavirus cases.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBoth are now at the same level as the Midlands city which was subject to the UKs first full local lockdown last month. Public health chiefs plan to impose lockdown restrictions in Blackburn from July  after failing to reduce the population’s stubbornly high infection rate. It currently stands at  cases per , residents - second only to Leicester and twice as high as anywhere  in the UK.The high infection rate is due to Blackburns large proportion of South Asian residents, according to the local public health director Professor Dominic Harrison.Almost three in ten of the town’s population are Indian or Pakistani.Professor Harrison has said the virus has sp widely in Blackburn because cases are “clustering” in the South Asian community, who are more likely to live in large, multi-generational households that are also more likely to be smaller terraced houses.Of  confirmed cases of Covid- in Blackburn in the first fortnight of July,  had South Asian heritage.Worryingly, one in five new cases were residents under the age of .Another area on the watchlist is Pendle in Lancashire which PHE have identied as an area of enhanced support.Bradford, Northampton and Rotherham have called areas of concern due to rising coronavirus cases. Health chiefs were meeting last night to scrutinise the latest infection data across Blackburn, which will inform how drastic the lockdown measures will be.It could involve a Leicester-style lockdown where pubs, shops, hairdressers and schools were closed and only essential travel was permitted.Or it could involve a lighter set of restrictions initially.A formal decision will be made on Monday, when the next review is due.A source involved in drawing up the measures said “plans have actively been made” for extra lockdown restrictions to come into effect next Friday. That date has been chosen as it is the day before a raft of new venues reopen nationwide.At the very least it will delay the reopening of venues scheduled to open their doors this weekend and next week.It means gyms, sports centres, swimming pools, beauty salons, nail bars and casinos in Blackburn will remain shut.Cllr Mohammed Khan, Leader of Blackburn with Darwen Council: “We need to keep up the momentum with our strong prevention work so we agree its sensible not to relax the easing of restrictions at the moment to stop the spread.“We have already decided to delay the opening of our council leisure facilities along with introducing other localised prevention measures.“We feel that accelerating our control measures in this way will assist us to move out of having higher COVID rates even faster - we are grateful for the Government’s help in our local plans on this.”It will also delay the changes in the blanket work from home guidance for workers in Blackburn, which are due to change from August  to allow staff toto their offices.And blanket rules barring all but essential use of public transport - due to be dropped for the rest of England next Saturday - will also remain in place.Small wedding receptions involving less than  guests will also not be allowed to go ahead in Blackburn.The plans are being led by the local authority, who have been praised by the Government for their proactive and sophisticated planning, in contrast to the botched record of Leicester City council.A government source said: “At the very least, the next set of easements won’t happen. “It’s a decision they’re taking locally and it’s been very locally led and we don’t want it to be Westminster saying this or that. “It will be gyms won’t be able to open in Blackburn as they battle to get their transmission down.”Last week Professor Harrison warned Blackburn had two weeks to reduce its infection rate or  lockdown measures would have to be re-imposed.Areas of concern have the highest prevalence of cases. The local area is taking targeted actions to reduce the infection rate with additional testing.Areas of enhanced support are at medium to high risk of intervention. There is a more detailed plan, with expert advice and additional mobile testing.Areas of intervention are areas where special measures are put in place that dfer from the rest of England due to signicant spread. A detailed action plan is put in place and local resources are increased with national support.A spike of cases in Blackburn earlier this month was blamed on a mass breach of social distancing rules at a funeral attended by  people.The imam who led prayers at the Jamia Ghosia Mosque in the town tested positive following the funeral on July .The service breached rules that cap the number of attendees at .It is not yet known when a formal decision may be made on restrictions in Luton.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sailors 1100 iphone working six days dropped in sea
story: Clumsy Ben Schofield’s device sank ft to the bottom of a harbour.Ben,  — a deckhand on one of the Dunkirk Little Ships — got a pal to e down to try to retrieve the mobile but they surfaced empty-handed.He refused to admit defeat and waited until low tide on Monday — six days later — before trying his luck again.He covered his shoes with plastic bags and climbed down between the boat and the harbour wall in Scarborough, North Yorks. He then waded through mud and after several minutes spotted his iPhone X.Ben, of Scarborough, said: “I went to show my boss and felt it vibrate in my hand. To my disbelief it was still on.“I cleaned it up, got rid of sand and grit from the charging port and let it dry out.“It only had three per cent battery so I plugged it in and it began to charge. Everything works. I contacted Apple and they couldn’t believe it. They reckon the sand filled the holes for charging and preserved it.”Ben works on the Regal Lady, formerly the Oulton Belle, which is now a museum.It was among the little ships that sailed to Dunkirk, northern France, in  and helped to rescue , Allied troops.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The London Mayor claimed yesterday that there were fewer people at Transport for London raking in more than £, a year than when Boris Johnson was in charge.But figures show they have gone up every year except one, where they dropped.Mr Khan told MPs on the Transport Select Committee yesterday: Unlike during the previous administration where the number of people earning over £, was going up and bonuses were going up, in the last  years they have been going down.He said that the number of people on high salaries had gone down.However, for the end of the financial year  , when Mr Khan took over the job as London Mayor, the total number of TFL employees earning over the huge sum was  - including Crossrail staff - according to figures from the Conservatives.That went up for the next two years - to a high of .It then dropped down to  before rising again last year to .Tory Mayoral candidate Shaun Bailey wrote to Huw Merriman MP, the chair of the Transport Select Committee, to raise the issue saying it was most concerning.He said: The Mayors statement is not a failed attempt at political spin. title: brexit deal not possible by july
story: David Frost said substantial areas of disagreement remain between both sides after the latest round of talks - and warned of a last chance to avoid No Deal.Both sides accepted that a deal would not be done by Boris July deadline -and No Deal could still happen in .He said he couldnt understand why it was so dficult for the EU to understand why Britain wanted a free trade agreement like Canada does.And he continued that considerable gaps remain in the most dficult areas, that is, the so-called level playing field and on fisheries.Mr Frost said: We have always been clear that our principles in these areas are not simple negotiating positions but expressions of the reality that we will be a fully independent country at the end of the transition period.  “That is why we continue to look for a deal with, at its core, a free trade agreement similar to the one the EU already has with Canada – that is, an agreement based on existing precedents.  We remain unclear why this is so dficult for the EU, but we will continue to negotiate with this in mind. Michel Barnier said at a press conference this lunchtime that a trade agreement at this point was unlikely and the EU was getting ready for a No Deal.He said we were still far away from an agreement but stressed the talks were positive and professional.There had been no progress in some areas and this week again the UK did not show a willingness to break the deadlock.By its current refusal to commit to fair and open competition, the UK makes a trade agreement at this point unlikely, he said.We only have a few weeks left, so we should not waste time.But Britain was more optimistic, with Mr Frost saying he was hopeful an agreement could be done by September and vowed to continue to keep working hard to bridge the gaps.Mr Frost warned today after the latest round of discussions: We must face the possibility that [a deal] will not be reached, and we must therefore continue preparing for all possible scenarios for the end of the transition period at the end of this year.A senior source close to the EU negotiations said this lunchtime that the talks were close to both a breakdown or a breakthrough.I can see how we could make a breakthrough relatively quicklythey do adjust their position in the most important areas.If they dont, we wont.If we dont agree on these points, there isn’t going to be a deal.Talks are at a stalemate and we cannot see a solution unless Brussels budges.It still simply refuses to accept Britain as an independent nation with our own economic rules and full sovereignty over our waters, setting limits annually on EU fishing catches.It pretends to respect our repeated pro-Brexit votes, then insists our negotiators must surrender fundamental rights, which would make a nonsense of them.Chief negotiator David Frost has commendably stood firm on the key issues. The EU does not make these demands of other major nations it negotiates deals with. Why with us If talks do collapse, so be it. Brussels may need a few years to get their heads around an independent Britain.Then, we suspect, a deal will be done.Its in their hands, to a large extent.EU negotiators will come back to London next week for informal discussions, with another round of official talks scheduled for  August onwards.Mr Barnier said today that the bloc was prepared to negotiate right until the th hour, even though both sides wanted one done ahead of time.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: andrew harrop keir starmer momentum
story: NewsopinionAndrew Harrop: Keir Starmer has momentum - now he must win back Labour backers who voted ToryToday is the first day of the summer recess - andLabour plays its cards right, it could be dangerous for Boris Johnson and an opportunity for Keir Starmer, writes Fabian Society General Secretary Andrew HarropShareCommentsByAndrew Harrop:,  JUL NewsopinionKeir Starmer getting a haircut as England slowly emerged from lockdown" %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailToday is the first day of parliament’s summer holidays. Ordinarily MPsto their constituencies to take a well-deserved break, catch-up on casework and enjoy a summer fete or two. Prime Ministers demonstrate their patriotic credentials by getting snapped holidaying in a UK seaside resort. And junior ministers and shadow ministers get their moment in the proverbial sun while the big beasts are away. This summer’s recess is going to be a time of great unknowns Both the PM and his Labour counterpart will be strategically planning maximum use of the time, whilst bracing themselves for the next stages of the coronavirus crisis. The approach required is the same, but for dferent reasons. And for the PM the next six weeks could spell trouble. Without the daily routines of Westminster and the verbal jousts of the House of Commons there will be a gap in the headlines. The Government’s ability to control the agenda with a daily stream of seemingly positive news will be limited.  Johnson has already stumbled badly in his response to the pandemic, from the deadly mismanagement of care homes to his inability to get all his cabinet ministers to give the same advice in public. The PM will be out and about shoring up public support because he knows he needs to hang onto people who aren’t naturally Tory voters.  He’ll be offering some turbo-charged ‘levelling up’ - but the slogans will be as questionable as they are brazen. And the likelihood is, they’ll be overtaken by Covid-related developments the PM can’t influence. In contrast, Keir Starmer has momentum. The Labour party is back in the ring and Starmer has passed the early tests of his leadership, showing judgement, competence and resolve both in holding the government to account and in starting to change the Labour party. He knows the job has hardly started, but most people’s impressions of the new leader are positive, which is all that can be asked after four months in office. Labour’s task for the summer is to continue making progress.  In  the party lost votes from every type of voter, in almost every corner of the country, something that Starmer doesn’t shy away from. The elections in May are coming into sharp focus and the Party must show real progress, particularly in Scotland. To do so, Starmer has work to do with an audience closer to home – his party, and former Labour voters.We can expect him to be spending a lot of time this summer in Scotland, as well as those ‘red wall’ towns in the north, midlands, and Wales. This is where recess favours him. Rebuilding those ties is best done outside of the parliamentary glare. Both Starmer and Johnson face a big challenge in cutting through to their respective audiences at a time when most of us would rather switch off.

story: NewsFace mask confusion as government unveils rules just hours before it becomes lawPeople in England must wear a mask or face covering over their nose and mouth in all shops and supermarkets - including when buying takeaway food and drinksShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsShoppers in Londons Oxford Street today were already wearing masks ahead of the rule change " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Tories finally published a full list of places where face masks must be worn just hours before the law come into effect tomorrow. People will have to wear one over their nose and mouth in all shops and supermarkets in England. Post offices, banks, railway stations and airports are also on the list. It will also be mandatory to wear a face covering when buying takeaway food and drink. Labour and retailers say the Tories have been mired in “confusion”.After months claiming masks were unnecessary or would give  confidence, No changed the rules as part of new restrictions in a bid to prevent a potentially catastrophic second wave of Covid- this winter. The UK’s official death toll rose today by  to ,, although the true figure is much higher. Ministers said face coverings are now part of the “new normal” and the public will be told to wear them for the foreseeable future. Stores can refuse entry to those without a mask or who fail to wear one properly. Police can use “reasonable force” to remove the shoppers and may impose £ fines. But officers say the regulations, which will be in place for a year, will be almost impossible to enforce. Venues such as eat-in restaurants, pubs, hairdressers, beauty salons, gyms, leisure centres, cinemas and theatres will all be exempt – as long as they have other protection measures in place.  It is already compulsory to wear face coverings on public transport. They can be fabric, such as a scarf, but research suggests home-made coverings need to be at least two layers thick, preferably three. The disabled and under-s are among those exempt from the new rules. People can briefly remove their mask , for example, staff ask for ID. Public Health England has warned parents not to use face coverings on babies and young children due to the risk of choking and suffocation.  Ministers have been urged to do more to protect those exempt from wearing masks after a charity highlighted “horric” cases of disabled people being abused. The public are advised to wash their hands before putting a covering on or off, and to avoid touching their face while wearing one. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: “As we move into the next stage of easing restrictions, it is vital we continue to shop safely so we can make the most of our fantastic retail industry... Everyone must play their part in fighting this virus by following this new guidance.” But Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth told the Mirror: “After weeks of ministerial muddle and Cabinet confusion finally face masks will be mandatory in shops. “Why it took so long to get to this point is yet another example of this Government’s slow response to the pandemic.” The Tory announcement came after last-minute confusion over how and where the rules applied.  Some ministers seen in takeaways recently wore masks and some did not. The rules clary that in places such as McDonald’s, you do not need a maskyou are sitting down to eat. Paddy Lillis, of shopworkers’ union Usdaw, said: “They are already dealing with more abuse than normal and this could be another flashpoint.” Some employers said they would not require their staff to wear coveringsthey work behind plastic screens. Tom Ironside, of the British Retail Consortium, said: “Retailers are doing all they can to support necessary safety regulations and will play their role in communicating and encouraging the Government’s policy on face coverings.  “While enforcement of this policy will be handled by the police, the ultimate responsibility remains with customers.” Ministers have been accused of mixed messaging on the issue. Kate Nicholls, chief executive of UK Hospitality, said the latest regulations contradicted what the industry had previously been told and it was “very late in the day” for confirmation. She added: “It’s really unhelpful to have that confusion because the single biggest thing we need now is to rebuild consumer confidence and that needs clear, unambiguous messaging.” Britain’s most senior police officer said she hoped any shoppers refusing to wear masks will be “shamed” into complying. politan Police commissioner Dame Cressida Dick addedstaff were worried and had attempted to handle the issue then officers would try to help. She said: “Calling the police should be a last resort for dealing with a mask issue.”

title: doreen lawrence leaves foundation focus
story: NewsopinionDoreen Lawrence leaves foundation to focus on creating national Stephen Lawrence dayStephen Lawrence was just  when he was murdered in a racist attack in Eltham, South-East London, on April  , sparking a campaign for justice by his mother DoreenShareCommentsByDoreen Lawrence:,  JUL NewsopinionDoreen Lawrence has announced she is stepping down from the foundation she set up " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHer campaign for justice for her son Stephen Lawrence, and refusal to give up in the face of overwhelming odds, moved the nation and changed the law. But Baroness Doreen Lawrence – who became a Labour Peer in  – announces she is leaving the foundation she set up in his memory to focus on creating a national Stephen Lawrence Day. Here, she outlines plans to make April  a global event through her new Stephen Lawrence Day Foundation. She also talks about Black Lives Matter and the disproportionate number of Covid- deaths among black, Asian and other ethnic minorities. Stephen, , was murdered in a racist attack in Eltham, South-East London, on April  .  The Stephen Lawrence Trust was my le. Every day for years, I was in my little office trying to turn Stephen’s legacy into opportunities and chances for other disadvantaged young people. We supported young people in architecture who wouldn’t have stood a chance and we opened our doors to creative and professional people who needed somewhere to learn their craft and get ahead. But then two important things happened. The first was entering the House of Lords, which was something I had never thought of. But the welcome I got from the peers was amazing. I realised my fight for justice was generating such levels of respect, his name was just getting bigger. It was not only being taught in schools nationwide but also being actively celebrated in the heart of Parliament, by senior people who genuinely cared about equality. I had less and less involvement with the Trust after the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge came to visit us at my request a few years ago but I was making progress in the House of Lords in other ways. The next big thing to happen was when then Prime Minister, Theresa May, told me she agreed my request for a Stephen Lawrence Day. The day she made the official announcement in St Martin-in-the-Fields in Trafalgar Square was one of the proudest days of my le. For Stephen and for others like him. Before him and since him. Innocent lives whose loss is now being recognised fully and properly. I realised I wanted to bring all the forces of good together, all the support I had received over  years into a day for all marginalised people who have suffered disadvantage or prejudice. The Day itself will be a culmination and celebration of activities and programmes that will run across the year. I wanted those forces of good to stand proud on a day which says: “Are we going back to the bad old days when it took a fight to get justice for a boy killed for doing nothing wrong ” No. We are not. And I realised I wanted to be hands-on in achieving this important national day – which defies anyone who still thinks, “What’s all the fuss about some black teenager being killed years and years ago ” I want such people to feel so out of step with their own country – as it celebrates a le like Stephen’s cut short by racist violence – that they know they are isolated in a tiny minority. Because the rest of the country is on our side, on the side of justice. So I decided to leave the Trust and start a standalone body specically aimed at making Stephen Lawrence Day a highlight of the year. A day for everyone with a cause which deserves justice. And a day of celebration of what we have achieved – across that year, until that year – and what we are going to achieve in the future. People kept asking me to say something about the Black Lives Matter movement and the protests after George Floyd was murdered by police in America. But I’ve always believed in action rather than words so I was busy building a new organisation which will say loudly and clearly on a UK national day for everyone that black lives matter. Black lives always matter, of course, and we’ll hold events, activities and build relationships which will shout this loudly across the whole year, every year.  That will be more effective than a few quotes from me stating the obvious that I detest and deplore the waste of innocent black lives… of any young le, any injustice. The BLM cause was well supported in the UK after George’s murder when thousands defied lockdown to take to the streets. I applauded their motives. They care and they are right to care. They put their lives at risk for what they believed in by going out marching. This country has been blighted by racism over the years and they were right to highlight the fact that the creativity and experience of black people has helped to build this country into what it is today. But marching and protesting is not for all of us and many people could not take those risks during a pandemic. As we know, black, Asian and ethnic minorities are especially at risk and lives have been lost. Next April, Stephen Lawrence Day will allow thousands of people, from the very young to the very old, families and friends to show the world that black lives matter by attending our national events. And this won’t be an improvised protest it will be an official Day, a nationwide expression against injustice and cruelty a celebration of tolerance and ersity. It will be a day for all disadvantaged sections of society, for everyone who has suffered prejudice or injustice.

story: AdvertorialMassively positive impact lockdown has had on families - especially those with teenagersA new survey from Very has uncovered many of the hugely positive effects lockdown has had on British familiesShareByDave Masters:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL Advertorial" %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMost parents say lockdown has brought them closer to their children, according to a survey conducted by Very. As restrictions ease, the Very Big Family Le Survey gives a glimpse of how le has changed over the past few months and how families view the “new normal”. The good news is that two thirds of parents of teenagers say all that time spent together at home has had a positive effect on their family. And the same applies to almost three quarters of those with kids under . Many families have created perfect memories by doing new activities together, such as playing board games, baking, walking and cycling.  Watching TV and streaming services have also provided family bonding time. Very asked parents to reflect on the past few months as they prepare for their children toto school full time. While for some it was stressful, juggling work, home schooling and quality time with the family, others found it fun and inspiring. Writer Gemma Cheetham lives with husband Mike and their two children, Ava-Violet, six, and Gabriel, one . She says the lockdown has made it feel like things have slowed down. She explained: For the first few weeks of lockdown I was working from home, and it was a struggle as Gabriel wanted to be with me all the time.  I’d end up logging on to work early in the morning, stopping at pm and starting again in the evening to make up lost hours. Normally, Mike would have taken the kids out, but when the restrictions came in he couldn’t do that. Then I got furloughed, and at first I enjoyed home schooling Ava-Violet and doing practical things like planting in the garden and baking banana bread.  But I started to notice a real dference in her. She just wanted to stay in the house. Even though we reassured her, she’d say things like, ‘I don’t want to go back to school, I want to stay safe and I want my family to stay safe.’ When her village school reopened, and she was in a small class bubble, she went back to her old self straightaway. She was glad to have the routine again, but she still likes having me at home. I feel like le has slowed down and we’ve been able to just appreciate each other’s company more. Another family feeling the benefit of spending more time together are the Blankstones. Mum Lisa and dad Mark live with daughter Olivia,  .  Estate agent Lisa told us: Olivia was due to sit her GCSEs and obviously she was upset when they were cancelled but since then she’s enjoyed being able to just chill out. I was furloughed, and Mark has his own optician’s which closed temporarily, so we were all at home. Olivia had schoolwork at first, but that eased off so we had lots of free time. We walked every day, exercised at home doing Joe Wicks and David Lloyd sessions. Olivia kept in touch with friends via video chats, and although she said a few times she wished she could see them properly, she was fine. She was disappointed to have our holiday cancelled, but she’s going to college and she’ll be more than ready to have some normality back again by September. We all get on well, so the biggest challenge for us was not being able to see other members of the family. Because he runs his own business, Mark said he’s never spent so much time with Olivia and he’s loved that. When you’re busy you feel like you’re always chasing your tail, but lockdown meant we all had more time.

story: NewsHero frontline nurses bid for Miss England crown after applying following night shtLizzy Willis, , was struggling to sleep when she ed home from her sht on the intensive care unit at St Marys Hospital in Paddington, London, and decided to applyShareCommentsByTom Hitchenor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsLizzy has been working non-stop on the frontline of the coronavirus crisis " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA hero coronavirus nurse is hoping to be crowned Miss England after applying following a gruelling frontline night sht. Lizzy Willis, , was struggling to sleep when she ed home from her sht on the intensive care unit at St Maryaposs Hospital in Paddington, London. She applied to the beauty contest on the off chance of being accepted - but has now got through to next weekaposs virtual semi-final. Lizzy was inspired to apply to Miss England by Dr Bhasha Mukherjee, who took a career break as a junior doctor to win last yearaposs competition. The dedicated nurse, from Maida Vale, West London, said: It was really really random.Follow all coronavirus updates here on our live blogI couldnapost sleep after a night sht one day and I was reading some news articles and I came across the previous winner, Bhasha Mukherjee, and saw sheaposs a doctor I just thought aposoh I could do thatapos I had a look at the website and just decided to send in an application and managed to make it to the semis.Due to the coronavirus pandemic, the contestants will not meet each other or the judges in person.They will be connected via the video calling app Zoom and submit their entries remotely. Lizzy, who is also a British Army reservist, added: The remote nature of it has definitely made it very weird.  We had a trial run the other day and it was quite interesting seeing everyone up on the screen. I guess when youaposre in person you kind of have a lot more freedom with your body language and how you present yourself and what you wear and things. When youaposre just sitting in front of a screen, I have only got a phone screen to record on. Youaposve just got that tiny window to present yourself and sell yourself, so it is tough. Lizzy started her nursing career just before the coronavirus outbreak last December and has been working round the clock ever since.  She said: It has been the busiest and craziest time of my le, definitely in my career. I only just started when this first kicked off. Iaposve been talking a lot with my family about whataposs going on because theyaposre also in the medical profession, so I know they can really relate to how busy and how crazy it is. We are working in conditions and pressures, unlike anything I’ve ever experienced. I had been a qualied nurse for four months before it all kicked off and suddenly I was expected to be more senior and teach the staff drafted in to help.  It was very surreal, nurses and doctors walking round in full PPE with patients either on a ventilator or needing constant monitoring to seethey were deteriorating. While not caring for the sick, Lizzy said sheaposs been focusing on the competition, adding: There are so many elements that there are to do. For example, thereaposs a Miss Eco round. Part of that is making your own outfit and presenting it to the judges. Iaposve been spending quite a few evenings sewing little garments and itaposs been really therapeutic after work.  It is made from old clothing and the idea is to reuse to make something brand new. The competition is something new for me but itaposs also a new way of working. Itaposs a new experience for the judges, let alone the contestants, but everything is very, very positive. You hear rumours that it gets very competitive and the girls are quite mean to each other but this has been very very pleasant.

title: how hero red cross volunteers
story: NewsInspirational Red Cross volunteers who have been so vital during lockdownAt the start of the lockdown we teamed up with the Red Cross for a Kindness Will Keep Us Together campaign and more than , have signed up to help someone in needShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsTheresa Mgadzah Jones has been helping single mums who are also refugees, through a partnership with the Birth Partner Project in Cardf " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThroughout the pandemic there have been tales of ­incredible bravery from our NHS staff and key workers. But alongside those have been the quiet, almost everyday acts of ­kindness which have changed lives and helped so many. At the start of the lockdown we teamed up with the Red Cross for a Kindness Will Keep Us Together campaign and more than , have signed up to help someone in need. From driving people to hospital appointments to shopping trips and delivering essential medicines, more than , acts of kindness have been carried out across the country. Here, just a few of those Red Cross workers, helpers, and those they helped, reveal what a dference it has made to their lives. Paul Hunter: Straight back into hospital suffering from coronavirus Paul Hunter contracted coronavirus early on in the pandemic, a week after being discharged from hospital following a leg complaint. Given his age, underlying health conditions including diabetes, breathing problems and having already suffered a heart attack, he was especially at risk. The -year-old spent around three weeks on the ward, during which time three people there died. Paul, from Croydon, South London, remembers: “It was scary. I had to start to take oxygen. I couldn’t walk, and I couldn’t stand.”  The dad-of-one, whose daughter lives  miles away, was visited by the British Red Cross’ local independent living team, which visited him wearing full PPE gear. Paul says: “They came and had a chat and asked how I was and everything. They said, ‘We’ll walk with you’. I walked up and down the ward and back again. I started getting a bit better.” After he ed home the Red Cross provided him with a walker to get around and a support worker. Scott, the support worker assigned to Paul, said of his Red Cross role: “A lot of it is... just keeping these people with their heads above water until some kind of normality comes back in.” Graham Bond: apos I found a crutch to lean on when I couldn’t cope’  After coming out of hospital following kidney surgery in March, Graham Bond struggled. The partially disabled -year-old found the transition back home disorientating. The Red Cross helped him with food shopping and gave him “breathing space” so he could arrange longer-term support. Former yachtsman Graham, from Tadley, Hants, said: “I was desperate for help. There was no food in the house and I was struggling to get out of bed, never mind get to the shops. My le was already a bit limited, but in lockdown it got even worse. “But knowing someone is there at the end of the phone makes me feel less isolated. It’s really helped me cope with the lockdown.” He describes the organisation as a “crutch to lean on when I couldn’t cope”. Debbie Lister, Graham’s support worker, says: Graham was our very first referral in the coronavirus lockdown period.It was the first time we had had to put on full PPE in a real scenario. We were obviously apprehensive but Graham’s operation had left him exceptionally vulnerable and he needed our support. Graham was... daunted about being at home on his own. We gave him the reassurance that we were available to support, in whatever way we could. Carrie Reid and daughter Amy: Mum and daughter working -hour ambulance shts Ambulance support volunteers Carrie Reid and daughter Amy have been helping people get to and from hospital. The Londoners are usually first aid trainers, but have been doing -hour shts, in full PPE, to transport patients. Carrie, , said: “We were told we’d be dealing with Covid patients. That was a bit daunting, mostly because of my age.But I’m a qualied emergency response volunteer with a nursing background. I would not be able to live with myselfI’d stayed at home and done nothing.”  Amy, , did not start helping with the coronavirus response at the same time as Carrie because she initially feared she had the virus herself, but she joined her mum once that was, thankfully, found not to be the case. She says: “I felt with the skills I had it was very important to step forward”. It is a physically demanding job for both of them, but there is also the emotional pressure to manage. Amy says: “Some of it has been hard but there have been a lot of positives. “When I saw the first patient clapped off the ward that was very ‘awww’.” Red Cross volunteer Mamadou: ‘I feel at peace here, it’s a gt’  Red Cross volunteer Mamadou is originally from Senegal in West Africa and left his home as a refugee in , eventually claiming asylum in Northern Ireland. Although he has a degree in physics and has a special interest in solar energy, Mamadou’s immigration status means that he isn’t currently permitted to take up paid work. However, that hasn’t stopped him putting both his considerable talents and warm personality to good use during these months of the coronavirus pandemic. Mamadou now volunteers three or four days a week with the Red Cross in Belfast, helping provide members of the public with short-term wheelchair loans. He says: “I like doing something to help the community – it’s a great opportunity and actually feels like a kind of gt to me. “I feel at peace here.” Theresa Mgadzah Jones: ‘Stuck inside, they are so lonely’  Theresa Mgadzah Jones has been helping single mums who are also refugees, through a partnership with the Birth Partner Project in Cardf. Project coordinator Theresa and her team support women seeking asylum during pregnancy, birth and the first months with their new baby. Theresa says: “After the restrictions to stay at home came into place, the Birth Partner Project referred two young mothers to the Red Cross. They had new babies, and as well as having another child, one of the mothers had an underlying health issue.” Before visiting them, Theresa spoke to them on the phone to introduce herself and get a picture of the kind of support the new mothers would need. She says: “They seemed very down. They told me it is dficult because of not being able to get out. They are stuck inside, feeling very lonely.” Theresa picks up food packages from a local hub and delivers them to the new mothers, along with formula, nappies and wipes for the babies. Adetola, one of the women supported by Theresa, says: “The first time Theresa delivered a parcel, I wanted to message her to let her know how grateful I was for her help. ‘Thank you very much for your help, God bless the Red Cross’ I wrote.” “Because I am shielding I only see my children, so I am happy to see Theresa and other people from the Red Cross when they bring the food.” Hannah Vaughan and Olivia Mountjoy: Pupils are made of the write stuff

title: landlords waiting kick single mums
story: NewsLandlords waiting to kick single mums on to the street when coronavirus protection endsHousing charity Shelter is warning of “a wave of homelessness” from August , when the Governments eviction ban ends and up to , renters may be at riskShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnistClaire Donnelly:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsWorking mum Jeanny Pribe and her family are facing what Shelter calls “a wave of homelessness racing towards us” " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAfter hearing the Government had suspended evictions during the coronavirus emergency, ­working mum Jeanny Pribe spoke to her landlord, hoping for some breathing space. “I fully intended to pay in full,” she says. “But I thought I might need a little extra time due to having less paid work.” In the event, she borrowed money from family to make sure the rent was paid. But two days later, she was served with an eviction notice – dated for after the Government eviction ban ends on August . The housing charity Shelter is warning of “a wave of homelessness” from that date and says , renters may be at risk of ‘Covid-eviction’ when the Government ban ends. Despite warnings from housing charities, Parliament went home for the summer this week without resolving the issue. By the time MPson September , the eviction suspension order will have expired by nine days – leaving some families facing winter on the streets. “I honestly don’t know what we are going to do,” Jeanny, , says. “One of my children has autism so really struggles with change. The rental market here has gone crazy. There’s nothing. I’m lying awake at night worrying myself sick because at this moment we have nowhere to go.” Polly Neate, chief executive of Shelter, says the Secretary of State for Housing, Robert Jenrick, promised nobody would lose their home due to coronavirus. “But that promise has been shattered,” she says. “The Government has gone on its summer break having failed to make the vital tweaks to the law that are needed to properly protect renters. “A wave of homelessness is coming. Hundreds of thousands of people could lose their homes following the evictions ban lting on August . Some people could even face sleeping on the streets this winter.”  This week we spoke to three working mums, all of whom now face eviction. Sarah – not her real name – has lived with her grown-up disabled daughter, Alison, in a rented property in Greater Manchester, for two years. The women both work in a factory, and Sarah also has two cleaning jobs. They had previously been model tenants but are now being threatened with eviction. “It’s been awful,” Sarah, , says. “Two weeks ago, my daughter took a load of tablets because of it all and had to be admitted to hospital. They’re still saying they’re going to evict us. “I’ve come back late at night from my evening cleaning job, and the landlord has had people sat outside the house. I think they’re trying to intimidate us. I don’t know where we’re going to go.”  The women fell short with their rent after Alison, who has arthritis in her spine, had a fall at work, and Sarah’s cleaning work dried up because of Covid-. “We spoke to the agent to seewe could pay extra the month after and sent a copy of the sick note,” Sarah says. “We just wanted a bit of time. But two days later a letter arrived to say we were being evicted.” Shelley,  – who also asked us to change her name – rents in the Wirral with her four children. Her income, as a self-employed cleaner who also takes in ironing, was drastically hit by lockdown. She got a month behind with rent but caught up again. Even so, her landlord says he now wants the property back.  “As soon as we get to August , I’ll have to leave but I don’t have anywhere to go,” Shelley says. “I spoke to Shelter because I was worried thatI don’t have anywhere to live, they might try and take my kids off me. The demand on houses locally is ridiculous. I’ve been so stressed by it all. My mental health has been really bad – I ended up at the doctor’s because it was making me ill. It feels like the whole world is falling apart. A roof over your head is safety, and we don’t have that.” Jeanny is studying for a masters degree and tops up her student loans working at a Clarks shoe shop, but hours have been dficult to come by.

the winter.Prof Whitty told MPs on Tuesday: #xCA surge in winter is a really serious concern looking forward and where I spend most of my thinking time.#xD:Fresh air quota in planes part of agreed EU hygiene standards for flightsEuropean Union states have agreed on common hygiene standards such as social distancing and wearing face masks on planes and at airports to help curb the spread of the new coronavirus, German Transport Minister Andreas Scheuer said on Thursday.#xCI am pleased that the German proposal was accepted by my colleagues at the European level and that we could agree on these unorm standards,#xD Scheuer told a European aviation conference.Measures agreed include mouth-and-nose protection for passengers from six years old and social distancing at airports during security checks and check-in. story: NewsMum who delayed seeing GP about tummy pains during lockdown has incurable cancerJohanna William, , a chef from Burton-on-Trent, Staffordshire, first started suffering from pains in April but held off seeking help as she knew the NHS was overwhelmed with coronavirus patientsShareCommentsByAliki KraterouLorraine King:,  JUL NewsJohanna Williams with her children Lillian, Lewis and Gabriel " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum has been diagnosed with incurable cancer after she delayed seeing her doctor about stomach pains during lockdown as she aposdidnapost want to waste their timeapos.Johanna William, , first started suffering from tummy pains in April but held off going to see her GP as she knew the NHS was aposoverwhelmedapos with coronavirus patients.Last month she went to hospital after the pain got worse where a CT scan showed she had two big tumours in her adrenal gland that had spread to her liver kidney and spleen. She was given the devastating news she had stage four incurable cancer. The mum of three from Burton-on-Trent, Staffordshire, said: I didnapost want to waste the doctorsapos time for a tummy ache, the NHS had so much going on. In June the pain got so bad I went to the hospital. Originally they thought they were two cysts but after the radiologists had a look at them they confirmed they were two tumours. I had to wait a week to hear back from the oncology specialist- it was a very long week. I was in shock, it never crossed my mind, a stomach ache could have been cancer. I was thinking I might have eaten the wrong thing or maybe I have an intolerance to dairy or something like that.  Never in a million years I thought it was going to be as bad as it is. The chef, whose mum to Lewis, , Lillian,  and eight-year-old Gabriel, was diagnosed with appendicitis before lockdown after experiencing tummy trouble. Since the cancer diagnosis, Johanna has started aggressive chemotherapy for the next six months. She added: Itaposs such a rare type of cancer, the only reason they found out was because of the CT scan.  I had a blood test in the spring and was told I had inflammation of the appendix- the doctors prescribed antibiotics and painkillers for appendicitis and sent me home. Because of Covid-, they couldnapost do CT scans or surgery - all non-essential procedures had been stopped due to the virus. If I never had the appendicitis symptoms they would never have found out. Her best friend and neighbour Nichola Baker,  has set up a GoFund me page to help her make some memories with her children before she gets worse.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailRules around bank branch ­closures have been branded a box-ticking exercise as they do ­nothing to stop the tide of cuts to the UK’s network. Consumer champion Which  says despite the introduction of an Access to Banking code in , which requires banks to assess the impact on communities of branch cuts, more than a third have gone over the past five years. Which  found HSBC, Lloyds Banking Group, Santander, the Co-operative Bank, TSB and Virgin Money have never reversed a closure decision. Collectively hey have shut more than  branches since the code came into effect.  Closures announced for this year could lead a further  to go, although banks including HSBC and Lloyds Banking Group have paused plans due to the coronavirus.Banks are required to carry out an impact assessment around a decision to close a branch and provide details of issues raised by consumers. Which  found more than half of customers polled used their branch at least once a month before it closed. One in ten had read the impact assessments banks must publish. Jenny Ross, Which  money editor, said: “The network continues to shrink at an alarming rate, and the way the Access to Banking Standard is being ­implemented suggests the impact – particularly on vulnerable customers – is going unchecked.”

Deirdre Jenkins, , led a secret double le peddling the Class-A drug in a tiny rural Welsh village. The mum-of-two even allowed some customers to buy cocaine on credit, with one owing her £,. When she was arrested police found three wraps of cocaine in her handbag and g of the drug hidden in a bedroom cupboard. Officers also discovered £ in cash at her home, which was next to the Post Office where she worked. Judge Catherine Richards told Jenkins she “enjoyed the status” of being a drug dealer. The Princess of Wales wrote to Dudley Poplak to thank him for three drawings he had produced for her to mark her th birthday in July  - a year before she separated from Prince Charles and six years before she was killed in a car crash in Paris. The handwritten note has come to light as it goes on sale, expected to fetch about £. She wrote: I do wonder what the next ten years will bring, the last ten I have learnt a great deal in an interesting way! Charles and Diana had a notoriously dficult marriage in which both are acknowledged to have had extra-marital affairs. One le-lesson Diana may have been referring to was how, two years before she wrote the letter, she confronted Camilla Parker Bowles over her affair with Charles. Her pondering of what the future might hold is all the more poignant as she died alongside her new-found love Dodi Fayed at the age of . The letter, on Kensington Palace-headed notepaper, has emerged  years later after it was put up for public auction by a retired autograph and manuscripts dealer.  Alongside it is a separate note by her mother, Frances Shand Kydd, in which she wrote how her son Charles Spencer apostook on the worldapos in his famous eulogy to his sister at her funeral at Westminster Abbey. The items are being sold by David Lay Auctioneers of Penzance, Cornwall, for an estimated £. The Diana letter is dated June , , four days before her th birthday.  It is not clear what the drawings Mr Poplak gave to Diana were but they appeared to be relevant to the whole Spencer family. She confessed that she had already opened them before the big day. She added: Since when have I beable to keep a present for the right day  Iaposm afraid your three wonderful drawings were no exception! She then made a joke at the expense of her stepmother Raine Spencer who it seems had a reputation for selling family items.  Diana said: I am deeply touched to be given something that means such a lot to our family  that Raine hasnapost put under auction! The Princess went on the add the touching line about her future. She wrote: I do wonder what the next ten years will bring, the last ten I have learnt a great deal in an interesting way! The note from Frances Shand Kydd was written four months after Dianaaposs death. The late Mrs Shand Kydd was writing after she had delivered her own speech at a memorial mass for Diana at St Columbaaposs Cathedral in Oban in Scotland, where she lived. She admitted that she was aposseared rigidapos with nerves before her delivery but added apos...since my children had taken on the world in the Abbey I really thought their mum should be able to do her home pitch!apos Mimo Connell Lay, of David Lay Auctioneers, said: These two items are from a retired dealer who is selling some of his most treasured items that he has kept for years. The letter from Diana is quite short but the content is strong.
